captions.text:
Wassap ballas? This week we have no idea what the
fu** is going on with Slaughterhouse-Five by Kurt
Vonnegut.

Now let’s get somethin straight,
playboy. The first chapter of this book ain’t

exactly like the rest. Here, we chillin with
a narrator who sounds A LOT like Kurt Vonnegut.

This fool been tryin to write about livin’
through the bombing of Dresden back in Dub-Dub

Deuce. But since nothing in war makes a damn
bit of sense, the story he gonna tell us is
just a big ol mind-fu**.

Billy Pilgrim musta smoked too much
o dat chronic cuz this fool is “unstuck

in time”- meanin he always jumpin through
random moments in his life and he can’t
do nuthin bout it.

As he crawling through the sh**
rollin 4 deep, Billy wanders away, gets unstuck

in time, and WACK he time-trips to his future
as a creased-up optometrist. And after trippin

through other life events, BAM Billy slides
on back to the war and gets GOT by the Germans.

Our boy gets his ass tossed on a
train when ZOW, back to the future, B. And

now- here comes some MUTHAfu**IN ALIENS IN
A MUTHAfu**IN FLYING SAUCER.

Billy takes one look at these green
hustlas called Tralfamadorians and be like

“yo. Why me??” And they all like “Why
anything? sh** just is.”

ZIP ZAP, playa. Back on the train,
and now peeps be dyin left and right. They

reach the camp and ZOOP- Billy trips to the
alien crib where they got him locked up like

a zoo animal. Ain’t all bad though, cuz
he gets locked up with a bangin movie star
named Montana Wildhack.

ZEFF! Billy wakes up right
before it’s lights out. B-pill gets capped

and dies. That it? NOPE. HADOUKEN! Back to
1945 where the Germans put him and da other
homies on lockdown in a slaughterhouse.

When Dresden gets WRECKED by a
firebombing, Billy survives cuz he got put
in a meatlocker.

WANG! 25 years later, Billy gets on
a plane with some otha optometrist homies

when the damn thing crashes! One head-whack
later, Billy’s runnin his mouth on the radio
bout Tralfamadore and flying saucers.

ZAM. Back in Dresden, the
bombings’s over and errythings quiet. cept
for a lil’ bird say “POO-TEE-WEET.”

What the hell?! If you think POO-
TEE-WEET don’t make a lick of sense, then

well done playboy. Where’d you get that
P.H.D from?

All that birds jibber-jabbering is
a symbol for how the narrator feels about
war. Senseless.

That’s one of this book’s main
beefs: that there ain’t nothing smart to

say about war. And when you talkin bout the
death of 135,000 people, logic just don’t
apply.

No matter how fly your writing game
be, you can’t describe what’s indescribable.

And any time you try to do it justice, you
gonna end up with a story just like our narrator’s.

So instead of a rap with a beginning, middle,
and end, we get a version that’s all screwed

and chopped. The structure of dis book is,
in itself, a massacre.

When you’re in a world that’s so
damn broke that you cant even pick up the

pieces, the only choice you got is to look
at it differently. Some playas think that’s

why the narrator made Billy P an optometrist-
he corrects our vision of the world and helps

us see that bad stuff happens for no reason.
So it goes...

But good stuff happens to all those
that press subscribe. Catch you next week, padna.

title: Slaughterhouse-Five - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
Billy had a framed prayer on his office wall which expressed his method for 
keeping going, even though he was unenthusiastic about living. A lot of 
patients who saw the prayer on Billy’s wall told him that it helped them to 
keep going, too. It went like this: “God grant me the serenity to accept 
the things I cannot change, courage to change the things I can, and wisdom 
always to tell the difference.” Among the things Billy Pilgrim could not 
change were the past, the present, and the future.﻿

comments.author: xavierman232

comments.text:
+xavierman232 But to make it clear: I hope I have misunderstood you, or do 
you really think a Tarantino film (for example) makes a person less violent 
because he develops an awareness for (real) violence and its effects?
comments.author: Ragify7

comments.text:
Enjoying violence does not mean being aware of it! Being aware of it means 
being aware of it's effects and consequences (which Tarantino's films don't 
show). The violence of his films is not realistic. It's stylised and 
gloryfied. The viewer can only be aware of it if it is presented in a 
realistic way (look at films of Bresson, Haneke, Angelopoulos, etc.).

Violence is NOT something that should be made consumer-friendly, in my 
opinion.
comments.author: Ragify7

comments.text:
well given the fact that too much is like not enough, if we enjoy
in some kind of way the immorality and the violence of our species, we are, 
in fact aware of it , wich mean more conscious. Therefore less violence and 
immorality in action.

Yo, dis is cool and all, but my man totally dropped the ball in explaining 
that the Tralfamadorians totally got this type of book where time is non 
linear. Dat kind of shit only contains moments in time that work together

comments.author: CQModels

comments.text:
Another important thing you should have pointed out was that the aliens 
might have been a symptom of Billy's PTSD. They're plunger shaped. What do 
plungers do? They remove blocked up shit. And Billy has a lot of blocked up 
shit inside him that he needs to remove. That shit inside him is guilt at 
having participated in the war and come out successful and alive on the 
other end. It's also his sense of inadequacy; the book always mentions how 
weak he is and at one point he even has to dress up in a toga and 
Cinderella shoes ( he's emasculated). He even marries an ''ugly'' wife so 
her Dad will make him more money. On Tralfamadore he can rewrite all that. 
He's kept in a zoo like how he was kept prisoner by the Germans (you 
usually keep animals in zoos and slaughterhouses [it's ironic that he 
survived the Dresden bombing in a slaughterhouse] ) but in the zoo the 
aliens think he's a splendid specimen and he gets to mate with a porn star. 
The Tralfamadorians' philosophy is summed up by the phrase ''so it goes'' 
which is repeated every time someone dies in the book. It's a fatalistic 
view of the Universe which removes free will and so removes guilt. If Billy 
can just convince himself that all the atrocities he has seen are 
inevitable (and that no one really dies but survives in a past that can be 
experienced all at once when you see in four dimensions like the aliens) 
then he can cope with the death and destruction and horror of the war, and 
remove any guilt he had. ﻿
comments.author: Alex Black

comments.text: +Alex Blackwell check out john green's summary, you'd like it
comments.author: Kevin Marzotto

comments.text:
An important motif you didn't mention is Billy's desire to die- to escape 
the life he has- and be reborn. That's why there are so many mentions of 
babies and Jesus in the book. In one chapter Billy is asleep in a green 
coffin-shaped wagon (as if he's dead). He's then woken up by two Germans 
who are obstetricians but never had a kid themselves. When he's woken from 
his coffin these baby-deliverers rebuke him like a naughty child for the 
exhaustion of the horses pulling the wagon. And like a baby who has just 
been born, he cries for the first time in the war. ﻿

comments.author: Sean Kelly

comments.text:
I actually understand Slaughterhouse 5 now. The whole "unstuck in time" 
thing is just a framing device, so that he can relate his story to 
something else. The Germans are the Tralfamidorians (sp). The movie star he 
gets on the flying saucer with represents him getting his final wish before 
his death... or rather, what he thought would be his death. It was a 
fantasy so that he could make peace with his life/with a bad situation.﻿
